html.p: What: Process events as they stream through, adding summary statistics to each event either individually or in a "window".

ol.li: There's a lot of options you can use for how to reset statistics, change windows sizes and so on. We'll touch on a few of these but see the docs!
Options for window=<integer> and time_window=<span-length> are probably the most commonly used.

html.p: How: |streamstats [all kinds of options here] function(field) [AS field], function(field) [AS field], ... [BY field...]
Why: Allows you to do all sorts of analysis that isn't easily done without it. Time-window math/counts, running counts, etc.

So What: Streamstats, especially with time or other windows, is really powerful and solves problems that are simply unsolveable without it. I also believe streamstats is probably the neatest command in all of Splunk.
We're using data we built earlier by using outputlookup. To build this see outputlookup
While yours may differ slightly, that data for us is:
Also, we'll use some data from _internal: index=_internal

panel.title: All kinds of averages and sums here

html.p: You'll see that "entries" is just a running count, running_tot_car is the total cars sold as of that entry, and running_avg_cars is the running_tot_car/entries.

search.query: |inputlookup rich_and_dave_cars.csv | streamstats count as entries sum(cars) as running_tot_car avg(cars) AS running_avg_cars

panel.title: The same as to the left, but by salesperson

html.p: A little harder to see because it's "by salesperson", but it's the same idea only there's one "thread" for each of us.

search.query: |inputlookup rich_and_dave_cars.csv | streamstats count as entries sum(cars) as running_tot_car avg(cars) AS running_avg_cars by salesperson

html.p: count will be a running count, and the eval builds a semi-random field test_field that trends upwards. Note the trend may be hard to see with 10 numbers - try opening it in search and changing it to count=100 then taking a look out near the end.

search.query: | makeresults count=10 | streamstats count | eval test_field = round(((random() % 10) - 5) + count/2)

html.p: Here we're "pulling a lot of shenanigans" to try to "level out" a running average of charge for my car on the old 110 "regular plugged in the wall" charger.
This is a dumb example because I had to mess around with it so much. But the idea is solid.
Smoothing the run-time of saved searches over a 3-item window. Just helps smooth out some jaggies, though still a bit of a contrived example.

search.query: (index=_internal sourcetype=splunkd) OR (index=_internal sourcetype=scheduler) total_runtime="*" | streamstats window=3 avg(total_runtime) as smoothed_runtime | eval smoothed_runtime = round(smoothed_runtime, 3) | table total_runtime smoothed_runtime
